data.text: Serious Touring Bikes Don't Have Suspension
"Serious touring bikes don't have suspension." Am I right or wrong?
Yes

data.text: Done most of my tours on a bike frame I took off a scrap metal pile. It was a 1960s frame, but it was Reynolds 531 plain gauge, which I think is ideal for touring. It was in the 1990s and I built it up with new mid range parts and rode it for another 20 years.

data.text: Depends on where you ride! Come in handy on bumpy roads. I've toured on mountain bikes since 1984.

data.text: Makes bike lighter, and one less mechanical issue to worry about.

data.text: I'd say those that conquer the Grey Divide ride would really like some suspension on parts of the rougher terrain and the option of a lockout for the fork when travel is not necessary. I doubt I'd do a tour that required front suspension tho
data.author: Topher Nando

data.text: I would say wrong. A front suspension and possibly a seatpost suspension improves comfort. You may not want to have FULL suspension however because I discovered it imposed a speed penalty and a substantial one when I had a double suspension mountain bike . However, if that is not important to you, then have at it. You can travel or tour on anything you have that you can pedal and have sufficient carriers and/or panniers to bring what you need and even want with you.
data.author: Norman Harris

data.text: Here’s another question. Why? If it’s a broad factual reason then I’d consider it. If it’s a personal preference then I don’t want to know about it. You do you and if I come across you in future then I’ll complement your bike.

data.text: Most of the touring bikes are steel frame, the steel frame itself is made to absorb the shock. If you tour with a front suspension fork MTB, I would suggest you to lock the suspension and change the tyres to narrower.

data.author: Brandon Howlett

data.text: Yes... 1) no-one should give a f*, nor should you 2) there is no such thing as a "serious" bike 3) the best bike is the one you are riding 4) suspension can be more than just nice on certain terrains
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: I definitely see what you are saying but do you consider pro level road bikes as "serious" compared to a steel frame Raleigh? I suppose if you are a pro, your bikes are very serious because that's how they earn their livings.
data.author: Todd Jackson

data.text: and who makes a living of riding a touring bike? Yeah... Exactly. And when you are competing at a professional level of cycling, you are riding the (best custom built) bike your sponsor cycle brand is providing you with. There is only adequate tools to get the job done. I rode 700 km across the Netherlands on a "omafiets" (no gears, only a coaster brakr) with a tent and sleeping bag strapped on the back and my personal stuff in a backpack in a basket on the front. That was serious. Ridden through almost every part of Europe on touring bikes, mountain bikes and fat bikes. There is no such thing as a "serious" bike. Every bike gets the job done, it's only up to your preferences if you want to do it comfortably, minimalistic, fast, luxurious or whatever. When you're taking it to serious (and not even getting paid for it), you're losing sight of the most important aspect: to enjoy what you're doing.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: right on. Touring Europe had to be incredible! Like you said, the only person who should care what they are riding, is the person riding it. I would love to bike the Netherlands. Sounds like an amazing trip.
data.author: Todd Jackson

data.text: A serious touring bike fits the needs of the person who is riding it. If someone has a spine problem and want to tour a full suspension bike would be the better choice. Not everything in life is about the most efficient way to do things (e.g. least rolling resistance whatever) but about creating more options to make people capable to do things.
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: The bike you take.. days the one. ...
data.author: Buck Murphy

data.text: Like everyone else said, it depends on where you are riding. I only ride streets and paved trails so my road bike has no suspension, aside from my elbows. I can speak from experience that a full carbon road bike with 23 mm tires on it makes you feel everything you ride over. That being said, you could could ride the same terrain on a different bike and have a completely different experience.
data.author: Todd Jackson

data.text: It’s more a matter of not being able to fit front panniers on a high quality suspension fork, I think

data.text: Depends on the terrain you plan on being on mostly, but, there is the element of having less parts to fail with a rigid bike. Generally I would agree but some suspension bikes are better than others for that purpose if you want to go that way. Other elements come into play, but, you have to decide the pros and cons compared to the path you take

data.text: If you need suspension take out some air of your tires. The rest is marketing
data.author: Kon Emma

data.text: A major issue is what type of road surface? Will you be mainly on well surfaced roads or a lot of roads of poor condition or unpaved? Problems with no suspension seem to crop up with sore elbows, rear end, and hands. I generally ride my bike that has front suspension only. However, I have it set to be very stiff and the suspension is usually locked. Only when going over rough roads (or trails) do I release the suspension. That saves my elbows, rear end, and hands. I think of it as adding a little weight to minimize medical problems. Alternatively, suspension can be built into the seat post and handlebar post.
data.author: Greg Goss

data.text: don’t see many people with the surname Goss, especially a fellow cycle. So I had to say hello 👋

data.author: Francis Genilla

data.text: I'm trying to build a serious rigid frame touring bike. First decision is tire size for giving yourself some cushion on small bumps without snake bites. I'm going to try a stem with an elastamer puck for prevention of hand and wrist fatigue. I could get a shock seatpost too, it's a common size. I consider anything more than say a Cannondale head shock to be excessive as far as real suspension goes.
data.author: Tim Greiner

data.text: Yes. Me too. I've decided to go for 26" wheels for several reasons. Maybe the most important is because I already have a couple of decent frames. But also, because the tyres and tubes should be available pretty much anywhere. I ride 2.10 slicks at home, but will probably go for knobbies in north Africa. And I'm going for v-brakes for the same reasons. Cables and brake blocks are available world-wide.
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: yes! And 3x7 drivetrain for the same reasons. You can replace the chain at any Walmart. I went for shorty V-brakes to mate with road levers.
data.author: Tim Greiner

data.text: Yep. Same drivetrain, but I'm going for a 34-14 rear and 42-32-22 front. Gives a low of 17" and a high of 78. If I do have to replace the rear freewheel with a 28-14, it'll still give me a low of 21"
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: similar to mine. Be advised, the 32 and 42 have very similar ratios a couple steps apart. I replaced the 42 with a 44, better but not perfect. I like the greater number of usable gears.
data.author: Tim Greiner

data.text: Maybe the issue is “serious”. By that I mean fun is important. Does serious apply to the bike, the rider, or the terrain? Tyres themselves have a degree of suspension, so do legs... I’ve seen tourers of full suspension MTB where I was on fully rigid with 2.2” tyres. I’ve also done 14,000km on 28-35c tyres on (mostly) good trails and loved that.

data.text: I would say yes, however when touring its about personal comfort and everyone is different. Surely the most important aspect of your bike is that it is fit for purpose and that it is comfortable enough to complete the miles you want to do over your chosen terrain. 🤔

data.text: I bikepack off-road on a full suspension mountain bike, for sure it's heavy and for some rail trail gravel type riding I'm seriously considering getting a gravel bike. But, I love being able to shred any gnarly downhill that comes along, plus I also like to know my bike is robust, and can handle anything thrown at it. Although preferring a full suspension bike, my heavy Specialized camber really isn't the best option for covering high KMs on road and gravel, for me.

I can use the Voyageur for road, the mountain bike for all-terrain . I think the seats and pedals , tires are important . You can do suspension post , or spring seat. I'm still deciding ..

data.text: I noticed A majority of people using some suspension in Germany where they have a far better system of touring…gravel and road They even have dedicated E-bike charging stations in the tiniest little villages
data.author: Hans Bogdanos

data.text: Neither. For several reasons: (1) An inconsequential opinion can't be right or wrong. (2) Bikes aren't serious or amateur because they're inanimate objects. Riders can be, but there's no world governing body for bike touring. Thus, whether a person is serious about bike touring is a question answerable only by that person. (3) Statements like this are typically uttered only to conceal the insecurity of the speaker. Knowledgeable, experienced (i.e., serious) people don't need to do that. Ergo, the speaker is an amateur and unqualified to make blanket proclamations about what is/not serious.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: wow, taking yourself a mite too seriously there dude.

data.text: Mostly true. No suspension means nothing to break.
data.author: Douglas Carr Cunningham

data.text: Assuming you don’t drive or use a smart phone or do anything that involves technology advancing. If people enjoy doing stuff and it get peeps out who cares.
data.author: Michael Roff

data.text: Both suspension and knobbly tyres are going to increase the amount of effort you have to put in to cover a given amount of road in a day. Those factors are going to make a lot more difference than the cost of your set up. A cheap 700c road bike with road tyres is going to be easier going than an expensive full suspension bike with off road tyres.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: It's a brave new world, just go with whatever makes you happy
data.author: Jonathan Spittlehouse

data.text: I have a road bike and did 40km in rough conditions and it still lasted! I only paid 390.00 😂
data.author: Sousa Ricardo

data.text: Well, serious touring bikes are usually made of steel, and steel absorbs a lot of road shock. Serious touring bikes usually have longer than normal chain stays so that saddlebags fit without heel overlap… Serious touring bikes usually have fenders, and front & rear racks… Serious touring bikes usually have a leather saddle like a Brooks saddle… The operative term is “usually”… Ride what you like and enjoy the ride!
data.author: Howard Maher

data.text: Most decent suspension forks have lock outs so you can have the best of both worlds
data.author: Jason Bonner Slark

data.text: My steele framed touring bike does not have suspension, but I agree with Dan. I plan to do a trip on my Liv Dash hybrid road bike next.
data.author: Mandy Lock Krumins

data.text: Right. Only SERIOUSLY serious touring bikes have suspension!
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: I think it’s down to taste
data.author: Jason Bonner Slark

data.text: Suspension can make your bike's ride less jarring when you encounter irregularities in your path, but it also adds weight to your bike and you may have to concern yourself with its maintenance, e.g., oil seals in your suspension fork and rear shock can break, you may need to carry a pump for air-suspended forks and/or rear shock, having to carry along fork lube in case your forks experience stiction, and if fully suspended you have different options for how to carry your touring bags. I'm all for less things to worry about and fix on any ride.
data.author: Bruin Longboarder

data.text: Those were my thoughts exactly. It's a sort of cost-benefit analysis, and the benefits pale into insignificance when the costs are considered.
data.author: Michael Papworth
